LOL! Tesla hs no competition. You want the best you get a Tesla. Everyone 
else is grabbing ankles trying to catch up and copy the bar that Tesla has 
set.﻿
Bloomberg is ridicously and childishly anti Tesla Motors﻿
Did ford pay you to make this?﻿

+Daniel May Ford paid for this ad to beg it's customers not to flee to 
Tesla. Too late, the horse has long since bolted and with the emissions 
defeat devices scandal engulfing the liquid-fuelled car industry coupled 
with free fast supercharging for all Tesla customers Elon Musk won't be 
able to keep up with worldwide exponential demand for the next decade or so.

We already do have an impressive charging  infrastructure.  The crooks at 
the major auto companies just want you to keep wasting money on gas.  Go to 
www.plugshare.com for proof on that and then here for ev myths 
http://content.sierraclub.org/evguide/myths-vs-reality﻿

+netsurfer912 also, i think electric infrastructure is quite a bit easier 
than gasoline - you have a huge station carrying highly explosive fluid and 
every now and then a truck has to come and fill that up, it can leak and 
the vapors are toxic - while electricity is already at *almost every home 
on the planet* xD
+Christopher Holmquist thanks!
Since the 1980's everyone Ford owner I've known have had issues with it. ﻿
Have any1 seen Ford Think vs. Jason Dawe? ﻿

Interesting article, but what they failed to mention is that Tesla is a 
company that's pure electric and turning a profit. If the other companies 
were really dedicated to electrical cars, they would dump gas only engines 
entirely.﻿

Not so fast - Tesla isn't profitable, yet and it's going to take some time, 
maybe 10 years before they reach that goal and it all depends on the 
success of the Model S, X and III.
But even if they crash and burn, they've changed both the industry and 
public perception of what driving electric means and have done and are 
doing more to build an ecosystem around vehicles that even what Henry Ford 
did in Dearborn, MI so long ago.
nice electricity effect, is this made for toddlers?﻿

Hybrid and Electric are totally different.... Why would people even put 
them together and compare them.﻿

+302yt ..to falsely make out that ICE carmakers are able to compete with 
Tesla's far superior products.

Tesla factories seem so much cleaner and advanced. Like Stanford/MIT vs a

trip to me.
Ford cant make a battery that  wont over heat.﻿

and safety! thanks ford, ain't buying your shit.

Tesla made batteries for the Toyota Rav 4 . there is comp for Toyota and 
Panasonic is not going to build cars. And ford is a piece of crap.﻿

He just said that they r hybrids Tesla is pure 100% electric stop trying to 
compare the wrong cars dude u r just wasting your time and ours ﻿

Waitasec... *Ford* isn't *'building batteries'* there... They are 
assembling battery packs.  *Tesla Motors* does the same thing on the second 
floor of their facility.  And the battery packs Tesla puts together have 
around five times the storage capacity.  C'mon, MAN!﻿
their batteries are so fucking bulky﻿

+Neil Leisenheimer just look at tesla. battery flat at the bottom and space 
everywhere.
+Napoleonicus It helps performance quite a bit as well.

Tesla battery packs are laid out flat across the bottom of the car. it 
leaves the top part of the car with a lot of space
It's powering a car, not a cell phone.  What were you expecting?
Simple fact of the matter is Elon Musk is cleverer than the competition.﻿
Is that an austin martin grill?﻿

"The future is electric" for cars that will need new batteries, and Ford 
Motor is building its own batteries.      ﻿
Old news﻿

Electric vehicles are the future.... no emissions.... climate change is 
real... we need to deal with the cause (fossil fuels)﻿

+Kenz300 x No Islamic oil required either - BIG national security bonus for 
the West.
Will I be able to charge these cars using solar systems at home?﻿
+Jason Nguyen jep.

Ford already missed the boat.. too slow... Tesla has the name and badge of 
the electric car. When you say electric car people answer Tesla.﻿

Great but what about fuel/energy mileage? If I can fully charge an electric 
car in 2 -3 mins then it's my kind of car. :)﻿

+Nicholas Cerbone But where are those batteries? Some car manufactures 
prefer to have them under seats for lower centre of gravity. As for 
Tesla..... it only last less than half of manufacture's claim.

+godzillat6 the thing with the whole "battery swap" idea is simple. you 
would pull up to a Tesla charge station. you have 2 options, recharge in 
20-30mins for free OR do a battery swap in under 2 minutes for a small fee. 
the way the "swap" works is easier then pumping gas. you pull up and onto 
the platform which is ground level and the whole battery swap process is 
automated. and you pull off. (the batteries are stored underground and 
maintained through Tesla themselves so you'd likely never get a bad battery.
I look forward to that.

And one more thing to add. This is very important for consumer electronics. 
Want smartphone that last 15 days without charging? Yes, we will have that 
soon. :)

As I have said, you need electricity to separate Hydrogen from water while 
if you use that electricity in EV's nothing is lost. Petrol cars have 
20-30% only efficiency while EV's 90%. That's very big difference. Also, I 
said before they have new battery and is only a matter of time we have that 
new battery on the market. Tesla model S can go 300 miles. Just imagine, if 
Tesla can go 300 miles now with old lithium battery, how far can go with 
new one? 1000 miles, 2000 miles? Thing is, petrol engines are at limit and 
is time for a change. Trust me, EV's are the future.

Hydrogens are surely dangerous but LPGs (Liquefied Petroleum Gas) are the 
most volatile ever. Hydrogens have similar mileage to petrol cars so how 
can their efficiency be that low?
We need to put new batteries into 24hr endurance races to prove their 
capability. But EVs are boring to live with except for Tesla roadsters. Too 
bad Formula Es require to change cars when batteries are low and in real 
life would you like to have 2 EVs? More importantly, how can we swap 
batteries when manufactures want to mount them as low as possible in order 
to lower their center of gravity? I would like to see whether if batteries 
can be fully charged in 3 minutes, if that happen I may change my mind.

Very heavy, 500 kg :)
It makes no sense to use Hydrogen cell simply because, you need electricity 
to separate Hydrogen from water. Efficiency is low and gas is dangerous. I 
agree that battery's are still heavy but very soon things will change. They 
developed new battery that have 10 times more capacity than battery's we 
use at the moment. This means , bye bye gasoline.

+Dino Sabanovic But how heavy are the batteries? Can u do that urself? It's 
great to swap batteries but what if you end having an inferior battery 
after a swap?
You can fill up petrol or diesel into the tank within few minutes where 
most batteries, you need @ least 15 minutes to fully charge. I'd go for 
Hydrogen cell which has the combination of environmental friendliness like 
EV cars, renewable energy like EV cars, fuel miliege of petrol cars and the 
ability to fill the tank as quickly as any petrol cars.

No, you can swap whole battery pack on Tesla in less than that! Do swap gas 
tank on any car ?

No quick charger, no sale. Level 2 just doesn't cut it Ford. I would have 
loved to have bought a Focus EV. I can charge my Leaf in 30 to 40 min with 
the CHAdeMo. They are every where I need them in western Oregon. Why aren't 
you listening Ford?﻿

I know Nissan is assembling its own batteries (they got $2billion federal 
loan to build their own battery production).  I think GM recently brought 
some of its formerly LG-only battery manufacture more or less totally 
in-house.  Ford barely sells any electrics (just enough for compliance in 
CA, while LEAF and Volt sell 2000-3000 per month and growing) and they're 
shoehorns of ICE designs, not dedicated EV platforms like the others.  So, 
yeah, whatever, guys.  

I can't handle Ford preening over non-achievements, especially since they 
just tried to lie to everyone about Energi and C-Max MPG, as if we were 
fools who would never realize that real world results tend to match most 
manufacturer's EPA numbers reasonably close.  Ford's numbers were a mean 
joke.  I'm almost sick of Ford's green poopoo marketing.  It's just 
grating.  The lies are grating.﻿

+netsurfer912 'Who Killed The Electric Car' is still very relevant today as 
an infomercial about the underhanded machinations of the Oil and ICE car 
industry even though we now have viable EVs available on the market at 
last, from low-end Leafs for Joe Average to Tesla's high-end beauties for 
those able to invest more in their car. Each tier of Tesla's development 
brings their cars closer to the reach of billions of averagely-waged 
consumers, and Nissan's Leaf can of course be upgraded with the latest and 
best batteries and charging techniques as the technology improves.

Poor Ford - sucks to not be Tesla eh?

+netsurfer912 "Who killed the electric car?" has lots of information on 
that. Definitely a must-watch for everyone dealing with cars. I think 
that's what I'm gonna watch right now.

+Bryan Seigneur exactly. let me add something to that though: GM has bought 
a very small advanced battery manufacturer's technology - he hoped that 
this would help them finally make great electric cars but *nope*: they 
disallowed him to sell or discuss it in any way. into their EV1 (which was 
an electric only car people loved) they still built lead-acid batteries.

This is two years ago and the so called "Competitors" / established car

them, have Nothing that can even hold a candle to the Tesla Model S... Hey 
Guys, let you in on a little secret... Tesla has Open Sourced it's patents 
and they would be more than happy if you reverse engineered them and copied 
them if you're having difficulty with the Tech Art...﻿
What a lie!!!!﻿

into the workplace.
Thanks Elon,you are truly an inspiration. ﻿

+naybobdenod  -- Actually, there is a means to store the energy.  The very 
same battery technology that Tesla Motors uses in their cars has been 
adapted for use with solar panel installations.  Solar City uses them 
already.  They can power a typical household for about three days.

+dlwatib I could`nt agree more but the biggest problem with solar is that 
we don`t have the means to store the energy for night time use.
People are working on this challenge and hopefully it will be solved,sooner 
rather than later.
Thanks for your comment.

+arale2k
Actually, nuclear plants are too costly. Solar power and wind power and 
natural gas can provide all the power we need.

yes but also more nuclear power plants to supply the demand in watts :(
the public infrastructure is not ready if everyhome starts charging their 
cars.
But I agree with you Elon is a true inspiration for us all !
peace

I think that once the *Accord, Passat, Maxima*, or *Taurus* is overtaken by

automobile manufacturers.  Some will throw billions at trying to catch up, 
while others will continue to ignore this segment to their eventual 
downfall.
